text: we have a continued stalemate in the
East where it is increasing increasingly
clear as my colleague Chris chippers
reports today that the rebel forces are
barely eligible for the term forces
they're so disorganized lacking in any
kind of coherent officer structure or
communications equipment or strategy
that it doesn't seem likely they're
going to be able to make much progress
against the Qadhafi forces any time
meanwhile a NATO has begun to step up
its airstrikes we heard bombs today
around Tripoli also rebels in the
besieged city of Misrata reported
yesterday that there were two NATO air
strikes which forced the Qadhafi forces
that had been seeing the port to pull
back in our lives here as reporters in
the city of Tripoli where we are working
at the invitation of the Qadhafi
government we had a little bit of a
scare last night when it looked like
about 26 of us were going to be asked to
leave the country the list was prepared
without much apparent reason including
reporters from a variety publications
with a variety of visa expiration dates
some people managed to get individual
exceptions through the course of the
night eventually I was one of them then
this morning a lower functionary told me
that I should pack my bags and get on
the bus and then there was no bus and
I'm still here in Tripoli little
anecdotal representation of how
decisions are made in the Qadhafi
government
